revisions.rev:
{{American Championship Car season |series = IndyCar |year = [[2005 in sports|2005]] |series_logo = |races = 17 |start_date = March 6 |end_date = October 16 |season_champ = {{flagicon|UK}} [[Dan Wheldon]] |champ_team = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Andretti Green Racing]] |rookie_of_year = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Danica Patrick]] |most_popular = {{flagicon|USA}} [[Danica Patrick]] |indy_winner = {{flagicon|UK}} [[2005 Indianapolis 500|Dan Wheldon]] |previous = [[2004 IndyCar Series season|2004]] |next = [[2006 IndyCar Series season|2006]] }} The '''2005 [[IndyCar Series|IRL IndyCar Series]] season''' began on Sunday, March 6 and ended on Sunday, October 16. The season, which consisted of 17 races, was the 10th season of the IRL since it split from [[Championship Auto Racing Teams|CART]] in 1995.
[[Dan Wheldon]] was the dominant driver in the series in 2005, winning six races, including the 89th running of the [[Indianapolis 500]], setting the record for most victories in an IRL season. However, the big story of the season was that of [[Rahal Letterman Racing]]'s [[Danica Patrick]], the fourth woman to compete in the Indy 500 and the first to lead a lap. She would eventually wind up in fourth. Danica's presence was a boost to the IRL's television ratings. The Indy 500's ratings were up 40% from the year before and subsequent races also saw a boost in ratings.
The season was also the last for [[Chevrolet]] in the series, who confirmed in August that they would not return to the IRL. At the start of the season, only [[Panther Racing]]'s [[Tomas Scheckter]] and [[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]] raced Chevrolet powered cars (although [[A. J. Foyt IV]] also started racing for Chevy beginning with the [[Meijer Indy 300|AMBER Alert Portal Indy 300]] at [[Kentucky Speedway|Kentucky]]). The manufacturer situation within the IRL was the hot issue during the second half of the season and continued into the off-season. [[Toyota]] announced that they would leave the series shortly after the 2005 season ended, leaving [[Honda]] as the only remaining manufacturer in the IRL. Honda extended their engine supply contract through 2009 despite expressly saying that they did not wish to be the IRL's only supplier. The IRL announced that they extended their chassis supply contract with Panoz and Dallara through 2006.

==Race Summaries==
===[[HomesteadâMiami Indy 300|Toyota Indy 300]]=== On March 6, at [[Homestead-Miami Speedway]], [[Dan Wheldon]] led 158 of 200 laps to get the victory. [[Tomas Scheckter]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Darren Manning]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] # [[A. J. Foyt IV]] # [[Paul Dana]]
===[[XM Satellite Radio Indy 200]]=== On March 19, at [[Phoenix International Raceway]], [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] won his first race of the season. [[Bryan Herta]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Darren Manning]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Kosuke Matsuura]]
===[[Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg]]=== On April 3 on the [[Streets of St. Petersburg]] ([[Florida]]), [[Dan Wheldon]] won his second race of the year. [[Bryan Herta]] sat on the pole. [[Andretti Autosport|Andretti Green Racing]] drivers swept the top 4 finishing positions.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Scott Dixon]] # [[Buddy Rice]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Darren Manning]] # [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]]
===[[Indy Japan 300]]=== On April 30, at [[Twin Ring Motegi]] in [[Motegi, Tochigi]], [[Japan]], [[Dan Wheldon]] won his third race of the season. [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Buddy Rice]] # [[Danica Patrick]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Darren Manning]] # [[Kosuke Matsuura]] # [[Tomas Scheckter]]
===[[2005 Indianapolis 500|89th Indianapolis 500]]=== On May 29, at the [[Indianapolis Motor Speedway]], [[Dan Wheldon]] won his first Indy 500 and his fourth race of the season. However, the focus of the race was on [[Danica Patrick]] who led 19 laps, the first time a woman has ever led a lap at Indy. [[Tony Kanaan]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Danica Patrick]] # [[Buddy Lazier]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Ryan Briscoe]]
===[[Firestone 550|Bombardier Learjet 500]]=== On June 11, at [[Texas Motor Speedway]], [[Tomas Scheckter]] won his first race of the season, sitting on the pole and leading for 119 of 200 laps.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Tomas Scheckter]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Kosuke Matsuura]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Bryan Herta]]
===[[SunTrust Indy Challenge]]=== On June 25, at [[Richmond International Raceway]], [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] won his first race of the season. [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Tomas Scheckter]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] # [[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Kosuke Matsuura]] # [[Danica Patrick]]
===[[RoadRunner Turbo Indy 300|Argent Mortgage Indy 300]]=== On July 3, at [[Kansas Speedway]], [[Tony Kanaan]] won by a fraction of a second over [[Dan Wheldon]] and [[Vitor Meira]]. [[Danica Patrick]] won her first pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Tomas Scheckter]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Darren Manning]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Danica Patrick]] # [[Buddy Rice]]
===[[Firestone Indy 200]]=== On July 16 at [[Nashville Superspeedway|Nashville Speedway]], [[Dario Franchitti]] won, leading 74 of 200 laps. [[Tomas Scheckter]] sat on the pole.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Scott Dixon]] # [[Danica Patrick]] # [[Ryan Briscoe]] # [[Buddy Lazier]] # [[Ed Carpenter (racing driver)|Ed Carpenter]]
===[[ABC Supply Company A.J. Foyt 225]]=== On July 24 at [[The Milwaukee Mile]], [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] won from the pole, leading 123 of 225 laps.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Tomas Scheckter]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Scott Sharp]]
===[[Firestone Indy 400]]=== On July 31 at [[Michigan International Speedway]], [[Bryan Herta]] won from the pole, leading 159 of 200 laps.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Bryan Herta]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Tomas Scheckter]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Buddy Lazier]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]] # [[Ryan Briscoe]]
===[[Kentucky Indy 300|AMBER Alert Portal Indy 300]]=== On August 14 at [[Kentucky Speedway]], [[Scott Sharp]] won for the first time since 2003 at [[Twin Ring Motegi]], holding off [[Vitor Meira]] for the last laps to win. [[Danica Patrick]] sat on the pole for the second time in the season after rain washed out qualifying and the starting grid was determined by the fastest times in practice.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Buddy Lazier]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Kosuke Matsuura]] # [[A. J. Foyt IV]] # [[Jimmy Kite]]
===[[Honda Indy 225]]=== On August 21 at [[Pikes Peak International Raceway]], [[Penske Racing]] teammates [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] and [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] started 1-2. [[Dan Wheldon]] won his fifth race of the season, tying [[Sam Hornish Jr.]]'s record for most victories in a season. This was the final IRL race at PPIR as the track was sold for redevelopment at the end of the 2005 season.
'''Top Ten Results''' # [[Dan Wheldon]] # [[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] # [[Tony Kanaan]] # [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] # [[Vitor Meira]] # [[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]] # [[Dario Franchitti]] # [[Danica Patrick]] # [[Scott Sharp]] # [[Patrick Carpentier]]
===[[Peak Antifreeze & Motor Oil Indy Grand Prix|Argent Mortgage Indy Grand Prix]]=== On August 28 at the circuit's inaugural race at [[Infineon Raceway]], [[Tony Kanaan]] won the race, taking the lead on lap 52 from points leader [[Dan Wheldon]], who was hampered by fuel problems all day and finished out of the race in 18th. [[Ryan Briscoe]] sat on the pole, but caused a three-car accident on lap 18 that also eliminated [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] and [[Danica Patrick]] from the race.
'''Top Ten Results''' #[[Tony Kanaan]] #[[Buddy Rice]] #[[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] #[[Patrick Carpentier]] #[[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]] #[[Kosuke Matsuura]] #[[Scott Dixon]] #[[Dario Franchitti]] #[[Vitor Meira]] #[[Jeff Bucknum]]
===[[Peak Antifreeze & Motor Oil Indy 300|Peak Antifreeze Indy 300]]=== On September 11 at [[Chicagoland Speedway]], [[Dan Wheldon]] won his sixth race, breaking the all-time record for most wins in an IRL season. [[Ryan Briscoe]] was involved in a fiery crash with [[Alex Barron (racing driver)|Alex Barron]] on lap 20. Briscoe was taken by helicopter to a Chicago-area hospital with head and back pain, but was alert. He suffered a [[concussion]], two broken [[collarbone]]s, a bruised [[lung]] and contusions to his arms and legs. The accident resulted in a 16-minute red flag.
'''Top Ten Results''' #[[Dan Wheldon]] #[[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] #[[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] #[[Tomas Scheckter]] #[[Tony Kanaan]] #[[Danica Patrick]] #[[Vitor Meira]] #[[Scott Sharp]] #[[Patrick Carpentier]] #[[Buddy Lazier]]
===[[Camping World Grand Prix at The Glen|Watkins Glen Indy Grand Prix]]=== On September 25 at [[Watkins Glen International]], [[Scott Dixon]] won his first race since his 2003 IndyCar Series Championship season. [[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] sat on the pole. This was the first major open-wheeled race at Watkins Glen since 1981.
'''Top Ten Results''' #[[Scott Dixon]] #[[Tony Kanaan]] #[[Dario Franchitti]] #[[Giorgio Pantano]] #[[Dan Wheldon]] #[[Kosuke Matsuura]] #[[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] #[[Bryan Herta]] #[[Scott Sharp]] #[[Patrick Carpentier]]
===[[Toyota Indy 400]]=== On October 16 at [[Auto Club Speedway|California Speedway]], [[Dario Franchitti]] won his second race of the year over [[Tony Kanaan]] by 0.111 s. [[Chevrolet]] powered cars finished 7th and 8th in their final IRL race while [[Toyota]] powered cars had a best finish of 5th in theirs.
'''Top Ten Results''' #[[Dario Franchitti]] #[[Tony Kanaan]] #[[Vitor Meira]] #[[Scott Sharp]] #[[Sam Hornish, Jr.]] #[[Dan Wheldon]] #[[Tomas Scheckter]] #[[TomÃ¡Å¡ Enge]] #[[HÃ©lio Castroneves]] #[[Scott Dixon]]

Result |- bgcolor="#FFFFBF" | Gold | Winner |- bgcolor="#DFDFDF" | Silver | 2nd place |- bgcolor="#FFDF9F" | Bronze | 3rd place |- bgcolor="#DFFFDF" | Green | 4th & 5th place |- bgcolor="#CFEAFF" | Light Blue | 6th-10th place |- bgcolor="#CFCFFF" | Dark Blue | Finished<br />(Outside Top 10) |- bgcolor="#EFCFFF" | Purple | Did not finish<br />(Ret) |- bgcolor="#FFCFCF" | Red | Did not qualify<br />(DNQ) |- bgcolor="#DFC484" | Brown | Withdrawn<br />(Wth) |- bgcolor="#000000" style="color:white" | Black | Disqualified<br />(DSQ) |- bgcolor="#FFFFFF" | rowspan="1" | White | Did not start<br />(DNS) |- | rowspan="2" | Blank | Did not<br />participate<br />(DNP) |- | Not competing |} |- | {| style="margin-right:0; font-size:85%; text-align:center;" class="wikitable" |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center colspan=2|'''In-line notation''' |- |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|'''Bold''' |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|[[Pole position]] |- |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|''Italics'' |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|Ran fastest race lap |- |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|<nowiki>*</nowiki> |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|Led most race laps<br />(3 points)</span> |- |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|<nowiki>DNS</nowiki> |bgcolor="#F2F2F2" align=center|Any driver who qualifies<br>but does not start (DNS),<br>earns all the points<br>had they taken part. |- |bgcolor="#FDE910" align=center colspan=2|Rookie of the Year |- |bgcolor="Orange" align=center colspan=2|Rookie |} |} |}

Points | 50 | 40 | 35 | 32 | 30 | 28 | 26 | 24 | 22 | 20 | 19 | 18 | 17 | 16 | 15 | 14 | 13 | 12 | 12 | 12 | 12 | 12 | 12 | 12 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 | 10 |} * Ties in points broken by number of wins, followed by number of 2nds, 3rds, etc., and then by number of pole positions, followed by number of times qualified 2nd, etc.
